| 1642 | [Blaise Pascal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blaise_Pascal "Blaise Pascal") invented a [mechanical calculator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_calculator "Mechanical calculator"),[[b]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-23) the first [digital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_data "Digital data")[calculating machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal%27s_calculator "Pascal's calculator").[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-24) |
| 1647 | [René Descartes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes "René Descartes") proposed that bodies of animals are nothing more than complex machines (but that mental phenomena are of a different "substance").[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-25) |
| 1654 | [Blaise Pascal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blaise_Pascal "Blaise Pascal") described how to find [expected values](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value "Expected value") in probability, in 1662 [Antoine Arnauld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antoine_Arnauld "Antoine Arnauld") published a formula to find the maximum [expected value](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value "Expected value"), and in 1663, [Gerolamo Cardano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerolamo_Cardano "Gerolamo Cardano")'s solution to the same problems was published 116 years after it was written. The theory of probability was further developed by [Jacob Bernoulli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_Bernoulli "Jacob Bernoulli") and [Pierre-Simon Laplace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre-Simon_Laplace "Pierre-Simon Laplace") in the 18th century.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20218-26) Probability theory would become central to AI and machine learning from the 1990s onward. |
| 1672 | [Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz "Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz") improved the earlier machines, making the [Stepped Reckoner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stepped_Reckoner "Stepped Reckoner") to do [multiplication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiplication "Multiplication") and [division](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Division_(mathematics) "Division (mathematics)").[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCorduck200441%E2%80%9342-27) |
| 1676 | [Leibniz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz "Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz") derived the [chain rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain_rule "Chain rule").[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-leibniz1676-28) The rule is used by AI to train neural networks, for example the [backpropagation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation") algorithm uses the chain rule.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) |
| 1679 | [Leibniz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz "Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz") developed a universal calculus of reasoning ([alphabet of human thought](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_of_human_thought "Alphabet of human thought")) by which arguments could be decided mechanically. It assigned a specific number to each object in the world, as a prelude to an algebraic solution to all possible problems.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-29) |
| 1726 | [Jonathan Swift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Swift "Jonathan Swift") published _[Gulliver's Travels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulliver%27s\_Travels "Gulliver's Travels")_, which includes this description of [the Engine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Engine "The Engine"), a machine on the island of [Laputa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulliver%27s_Travels#Part_III:_A_Voyage_to_Laputa,_Balnibarbi,_Luggnagg,_Glubbdubdrib_and_Japan "Gulliver's Travels"): "a Project for improving speculative Knowledge by practical and mechanical Operations" by using this "Contrivance", "the most ignorant Person at a reasonable Charge, and with a little bodily Labour, may write Books in Philosophy, Poetry, Politicks, Law, Mathematicks, and Theology, with the least Assistance from Genius or study."[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-30) The machine is a parody of _[Ars Magna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ars\_Magna\_(Ramon\_Llull) "Ars Magna (Ramon Llull)")_, one of the inspirations of [Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz "Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz")' mechanism. |
| 1738 | [Daniel Bernoulli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Bernoulli "Daniel Bernoulli") introduces the concept of "[utility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utility_(economics) "Utility (economics)")", a generalization of probability, the basis of [economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics "Economics") and [decision theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_theory "Decision theory"), and the mathematical foundation for the way AI represents the "goals" of [intelligent agents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent "Intelligent agent").[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202110-31) |
| 1739 | [David Hume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Hume "David Hume") described [induction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_reasoning "Inductive reasoning"), the logical method of learning generalities from examples.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20216-6) |
| 1750 | [Julien Offray de La Mettrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julien_Offray_de_La_Mettrie "Julien Offray de La Mettrie") published _[L'Homme Machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%27Homme\_Machine "L'Homme Machine")_, which argued that human thought is strictly mechanical.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCorduck200443-32) |
| 1763 | [Thomas Bayes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Bayes "Thomas Bayes")'s work _[An Essay Towards Solving a Problem in the Doctrine of Chances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/An\_Essay\_Towards\_Solving\_a\_Problem\_in\_the\_Doctrine\_of\_Chances "An Essay Towards Solving a Problem in the Doctrine of Chances")_, published two years after his death, laid the foundations of [Bayes' theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayes%27_theorem "Bayes' theorem") and used in modern AI in [Bayesian networks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_networks "Bayesian networks").[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20218-26) |
| 1769 | [Wolfgang von Kempelen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfgang_von_Kempelen "Wolfgang von Kempelen") built and toured with his [chess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chess "Chess")-playing [automaton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automaton "Automaton"), [The Turk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_Turk "Mechanical Turk"), which Kempelen claimed could defeat human players.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCorduck200417-33) The Turk was later shown to be a [hoax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoax "Hoax"), involving a human chess player. |
| 1795–1805 | The simplest kind of [artificial neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_neural_network "Artificial neural network") is the linear network. It has been known for over two centuries as the [method of least squares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Method_of_least_squares "Method of least squares") or [linear regression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_regression "Linear regression"). It was used as a means of finding a good rough linear fit to a set of points by [Adrien-Marie Legendre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrien-Marie_Legendre "Adrien-Marie Legendre") (1805)[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-34) and [Carl Friedrich Gauss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Friedrich_Gauss "Carl Friedrich Gauss") (1795)[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-gauss1795-35) for the prediction of planetary movement.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9)[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-36) |
| 1800 | [Joseph Marie Jacquard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Marie_Jacquard "Joseph Marie Jacquard") created a [programmable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_program "Computer program") loom, based on earlier inventions by [Basile Bouchon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basile_Bouchon "Basile Bouchon") (1725), Jean-Baptiste Falcon (1728) and [Jacques Vaucanson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Vaucanson "Jacques Vaucanson") (1740).[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-37) Replaceable [punched cards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punched_cards "Punched cards") controlled sequences of operations in the process of manufacturing [textiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Textile "Textile"). This may have been the first industrial software for [commercial enterprises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_enterprise "Commercial enterprise").[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) |
| 1818 | [Mary Shelley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Shelley "Mary Shelley") published the story of _[Frankenstein; or the Modern Prometheus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankenstein "Frankenstein")_, a fictional consideration of the ethics of creating [sentient](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentience "Sentience") beings.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCorduck200419%E2%80%9325-38) |
| 1822–1859 | [Charles Babbage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Babbage "Charles Babbage")&[Ada Lovelace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ada_Lovelace "Ada Lovelace") worked on [programmable mechanical calculating machines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Difference_engine "Difference engine").[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-39) |
| 1837 | The mathematician [Bernard Bolzano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Bolzano "Bernard Bolzano") made the first modern attempt to formalize [semantics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantics "Semantics").[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-40) |
| 1854 | [George Boole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Boole "George Boole") set out to "investigate the fundamental laws of those operations of the mind by which reasoning is performed, to give expression to them in the [symbolic language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_language_(mathematics) "Symbolic language (mathematics)") of a calculus", inventing [Boolean algebra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra_(logic) "Boolean algebra (logic)").[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-41) |
| 1863 | [Samuel Butler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Butler_(novelist) "Samuel Butler (novelist)") suggested that [Darwinian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Darwin "Charles Darwin")[evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution "Evolution") also applies to machines and speculates that they will one day become conscious and eventually supplant humanity.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-42) |

20th century
------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: 20th century")]

[![Image 5](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/AI-History-Timeline-300dpi.jpg/250px-AI-History-Timeline-300dpi.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AI-History-Timeline-300dpi.jpg)

AI history timeline image covering the most important events from 1900 to 2025

### 1901–1950

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: 1901–1950")]

[![Image 6: icon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/60px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)This section **needs additional citations for [verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:EditPage/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence "Special:EditPage/Timeline of artificial intelligence") by [adding citations to reliable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners") in this section. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed._(February 2018)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Maintenance\_template\_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 1910-1913 | [Bertrand Russell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertrand_Russell "Bertrand Russell") and [Alfred North Whitehead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_North_Whitehead "Alfred North Whitehead") published _[Principia Mathematica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principia\_Mathematica "Principia Mathematica"),_ which showed that all of elementary mathematics could be reduced to mechanical reasoning in [formal logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_logic "Formal logic").[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinskyIrvine20222-43) |
| 1912-1914 | [Leonardo Torres Quevedo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonardo_Torres_Quevedo "Leonardo Torres Quevedo") built an automaton for chess endgames, [El Ajedrecista](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Ajedrecista "El Ajedrecista"). He was called "the 20th century's first AI pioneer".[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) In his _Essays on Automatics_ (1914), Torres published speculation about thinking and automata and introduced the idea of [floating-point arithmetic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating-point_arithmetic "Floating-point arithmetic").[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-44)[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-RANDELL-45) |
| 1923 | [Karel Čapek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karel_%C4%8Capek "Karel Čapek")'s play _[R.U.R.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R.U.R. "R.U.R.") (Rossum's Universal Robots)_ opened in London. This is the first use of the word "[robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot "Robot")" in English.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-46) |
| 1920–1925 | [Wilhelm Lenz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Lenz "Wilhelm Lenz") and [Ernst Ising](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Ising "Ernst Ising") created and analyzed the [Ising model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model "Ising model") (1925)[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-brush67-47) which can be viewed as the first artificial [recurrent neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network "Recurrent neural network") (RNN) consisting of neuron-like threshold elements.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) In 1972, [Shun'ichi Amari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shun%27ichi_Amari "Shun'ichi Amari") made this architecture adaptive.[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-Amari1972-48)[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) |
| 1920s and 1930s | [Ludwig Wittgenstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludwig_Wittgenstein "Ludwig Wittgenstein")'s _[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tractatus\_Logico-Philosophicus "Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus")_ (1921) inspires [Rudolf Carnap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_Carnap "Rudolf Carnap") and the [logical positivists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_positivism "Logical positivism") of the [Vienna Circle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna_Circle "Vienna Circle") to use formal logic as the foundation of philosophy. However, Wittgenstein's later work in the 1940s demonstrates that context-free symbolic logic is incoherent without human interpretation. |
| 1931 | [Kurt Gödel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurt_G%C3%B6del "Kurt Gödel") encoded mathematical statements and proofs as integers and showed that there are true theorems that are unprovable by any consistent theorem-proving machine. Thus, "he identified fundamental limits of algorithmic theorem proving, computing, and any type of computation-based AI,",[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) laying the foundations of [theoretical computer science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_computer_science "Theoretical computer science") and AI theory. |
| 1935 | [Alonzo Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alonzo_Church "Alonzo Church") extended Gödel's proof and showed that the [decision problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_problem "Decision problem") of computer science does not have a general solution.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-49) He developed the [Lambda calculus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lambda_calculus "Lambda calculus"), which will eventually be fundamental to the theory of computer languages. |
| 1936 | [Konrad Zuse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konrad_Zuse "Konrad Zuse") filed his patent application for a program-controlled computer.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-50) |
| 1937 | [Alan Turing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Turing "Alan Turing") published "[On Computable Numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing%27s_proof "Turing's proof")",[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-51) which laid the foundations of the modern [theory of computation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_computation "Theory of computation") by introducing the [Turing machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_machine "Turing machine"), a physical interpretation of "computability". He used it to confirm Gödel by proving that the [halting problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halting_problem "Halting problem") is [undecidable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undecidable_problem "Undecidable problem"). |
| 1940 | [Edward Condon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Condon "Edward Condon") displayed [Nimatron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nimatron "Nimatron"), a digital machine that played [Nim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nim "Nim") perfectly. |
| 1941 | [Konrad Zuse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konrad_Zuse "Konrad Zuse") built the first working program-controlled general-purpose computer.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-52) |
| 1943 | [Warren Sturgis McCulloch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_Sturgis_McCulloch "Warren Sturgis McCulloch") and [Walter Pitts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Pitts "Walter Pitts") publish "A Logical Calculus of the Ideas Immanent in Nervous Activity", the first mathematical description of an [artificial neural networks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_neural_network "Artificial neural network").[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-53) |
| [Arturo Rosenblueth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arturo_Rosenblueth "Arturo Rosenblueth"), [Norbert Wiener](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norbert_Wiener "Norbert Wiener") and Julian Bigelow coin the term "[cybernetics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybernetics "Cybernetics")". Wiener's popular book by that name was published in 1948.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-54) |
| 1945 | [Game theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory "Game theory"), which would prove invaluable in the progress of AI, was introduced with the 1944 paper "[Theory of Games and Economic Behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_Games_and_Economic_Behavior "Theory of Games and Economic Behavior")" by [mathematician](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematician "Mathematician")[John von Neumann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_von_Neumann "John von Neumann") and [economist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economist "Economist")[Oskar Morgenstern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oskar_Morgenstern "Oskar Morgenstern"). |
| [Vannevar Bush](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vannevar_Bush "Vannevar Bush") published "[As We May Think](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/As_We_May_Think "As We May Think")" ([The Atlantic Monthly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Atlantic_Monthly "The Atlantic Monthly"), July 1945), a prescient vision of the future in which computers assist humans in many activities. |
| 1948 | [Alan Turing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Turing "Alan Turing") produces the "Intelligent Machinery" report, regarded as the first manifesto of Artificial Intelligence. It introduces many concepts, including the logic-based approach to problem-solving, that intellectual activity consists mainly of various kinds of search, and a discussion of machine learning in which he anticipates the [Connectionism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connectionism "Connectionism") AI approach.[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-turing-55) |
| [John von Neumann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_von_Neumann "John von Neumann") (quoted by [Edwin Thompson Jaynes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edwin_Thompson_Jaynes "Edwin Thompson Jaynes")) in response to a comment at a lecture that it was impossible for a machine (at least ones created by humans) to think: "You insist that there is something a machine cannot do. If you will tell me _precisely_ what it is that a machine cannot do, then I can always make a machine which will do just that!". Von Neumann was presumably alluding to the [Church–Turing thesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church%E2%80%93Turing_thesis "Church–Turing thesis"), which states that any effective procedure can be simulated by a (generalized) computer. |
| 1949 | [Donald O. Hebb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_O._Hebb "Donald O. Hebb") develops [Hebbian theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hebbian_theory "Hebbian theory"), a possible algorithm for learning in [neural networks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_networks "Neural networks").[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202117-56) |

### 1950s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: 1950s")]

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 1950 | [Alan Turing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Turing "Alan Turing") published "[Computing Machinery and Intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computing_Machinery_and_Intelligence "Computing Machinery and Intelligence")", which proposes the [Turing test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_test "Turing test") as a measure of machine intelligence and answered all of the most common objections to the proposal "machines can think".[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-57) |
| [Claude Shannon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Shannon "Claude Shannon") published a detailed analysis of [chess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chess "Chess") playing as [search](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_algorithm "Search algorithm").[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig2021155-58) |
| [Isaac Asimov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Asimov "Isaac Asimov") published his [Three Laws of Robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Laws_of_Robotics "Three Laws of Robotics").[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig20211007-59) |
| 1951 | The first working AI programs were written in 1951 to run on the [Ferranti Mark 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferranti_Mark_1 "Ferranti Mark 1") machine of the [University of Manchester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Manchester "University of Manchester"): A checkers-playing program written by [Christopher Strachey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Strachey "Christopher Strachey") and a chess-playing program written by [Dietrich Prinz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_Prinz "Dietrich Prinz").[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202117-56) |
| 1952–1962 | [Arthur Samuel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Samuel_(computer_scientist) "Arthur Samuel (computer scientist)") ([IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM")) wrote the first game-playing program, for checkers ([draughts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draughts "Draughts")), to achieve sufficient skill to challenge a respectable amateur.[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-60) His first checkers-playing program was written in 1952, and in 1955, he created a version that [learned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning") to play.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202119-61)[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-62) |
| 1956 | The [Dartmouth College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dartmouth_College "Dartmouth College")[summer AI conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dartmouth_workshop "Dartmouth workshop") is organized by [John McCarthy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McCarthy_(computer_scientist) "John McCarthy (computer scientist)"), [Marvin Minsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvin_Minsky "Marvin Minsky"), [Nathan Rochester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathaniel_Rochester_(computer_scientist) "Nathaniel Rochester (computer scientist)") of [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Business_Machines "International Business Machines") and [Claude Shannon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Shannon "Claude Shannon"). McCarthy coined the term _artificial intelligence_ for the conference.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-63)[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-64) |
| The first demonstration of the [Logic Theorist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_Theorist "Logic Theorist") (LT) written by [Allen Newell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Newell "Allen Newell"), [Cliff Shaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cliff_Shaw "Cliff Shaw") and [Herbert A. Simon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon "Herbert A. Simon") ([Carnegie Institute of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Institute_of_Technology "Carnegie Institute of Technology"), now [Carnegie Mellon University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University "Carnegie Mellon University") or CMU). This is often called the first AI program, though Samuel's checkers program also has a strong claim. This program has been described as the first deliberately engineered to perform automated reasoning, and would eventually prove 38 of the first 52 theorems in [Russell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertrand_Russell "Bertrand Russell") and [Whitehead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_North_Whitehead "Alfred North Whitehead")'s _[Principia Mathematica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principia\_Mathematica "Principia Mathematica")_, and find new and more elegant proofs for some.[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-65) Simon said that they had "solved the venerable [mind–body problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind%E2%80%93body_problem "Mind–body problem"), explaining how a system composed of matter can have the properties of mind".[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-66) |
| 1958 | John McCarthy ([Massachusetts Institute of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology "Massachusetts Institute of Technology") or MIT) invented the [Lisp programming language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisp_(programming_language) "Lisp (programming language)").[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202119-61) |
| [Herbert Gelernter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Gelernter "Herbert Gelernter") and [Nathan Rochester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathaniel_Rochester_(computer_scientist) "Nathaniel Rochester (computer scientist)") (IBM) described a [theorem prover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant "Proof assistant") in [geometry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometry "Geometry").[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202119-61) It exploited a semantic model of the domain in the form of diagrams of "typical" cases.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] |
| [Teddington Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Teddington_Conference&action=edit&redlink=1 "Teddington Conference (page does not exist)") on the Mechanization of Thought Processes was held in the UK and among the papers presented were John McCarthy's "Programs with Common Sense" (which proposed the [Advice taker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advice_taker "Advice taker") application as a primary research goal)[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202119-61)[Oliver Selfridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oliver_Selfridge "Oliver Selfridge")'s "Pandemonium", and [Marvin Minsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvin_Minsky "Marvin Minsky")'s "Some Methods of [Heuristic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_(computer_science) "Heuristic (computer science)") Programming and Artificial Intelligence". |
| 1959 | The [General Problem Solver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Problem_Solver "General Problem Solver") (GPS) was created by Newell, Shaw and Simon while at CMU.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202119-61) |
| [John McCarthy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McCarthy_(computer_scientist) "John McCarthy (computer scientist)") and [Marvin Minsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvin_Minsky "Marvin Minsky") founded the [MIT AI Lab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT_Computer_Science_and_Artificial_Intelligence_Laboratory "MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory").[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussellNorvig202119-61) |
| Late 1950s, early 1960s | [Margaret Masterman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Masterman "Margaret Masterman") and colleagues at [University of Cambridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Cambridge "University of Cambridge") design [semantic nets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexical_semantics "Lexical semantics") for [machine translation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_translation "Machine translation").[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] |

### 1960s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 1960s")]

[![Image 7: icon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/60px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)This section **needs additional citations for [verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:EditPage/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence "Special:EditPage/Timeline of artificial intelligence") by [adding citations to reliable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners") in this section. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed._(March 2007)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Maintenance\_template\_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 1960s | [Ray Solomonoff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_Solomonoff "Ray Solomonoff") lays the foundations of a [mathematical theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_theory "Mathematical theory") of AI, introducing universal [Bayesian methods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_method "Bayesian method") for inductive inference and prediction. |
| 1960 | "[Man-Computer Symbiosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man-Computer_Symbiosis "Man-Computer Symbiosis")" by J.C.R. Licklider. |
| 1961 | James Slagle (PhD dissertation, MIT) wrote (in Lisp) the first symbolic [integration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral "Integral") program, SAINT, which solved [calculus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calculus "Calculus") problems at the college freshman level. |
| In _[Minds, Machines and Gödel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minds,\_Machines\_and\_G%C3%B6del "Minds, Machines and Gödel")_, [John Lucas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Lucas_(philosopher) "John Lucas (philosopher)")[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-67) denied the possibility of machine intelligence on [logical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic "Logic") or [philosophical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy "Philosophy") grounds. He referred to [Kurt Gödel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurt_G%C3%B6del "Kurt Gödel")'s result of 1931: sufficiently powerful formal systems are either inconsistent or allow for formulating true theorems unprovable by any theorem-proving AI deriving all provable theorems from the axioms. Since humans are able to "see" the truth of such theorems, machines were deemed inferior. |
| [Unimation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unimation "Unimation")'s [industrial robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_robot "Industrial robot")[Unimate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unimate "Unimate") worked on a [General Motors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Motors "General Motors")[automobile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automobile "Automobile")[assembly line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_line "Assembly line"). |
| 1963 | Thomas Evans' program, ANALOGY, written as part of his PhD work at MIT, demonstrated that computers can solve the same [analogy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analogy "Analogy") problems as are given on [IQ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence_quotient "Intelligence quotient") tests. |
| [Edward Feigenbaum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Feigenbaum "Edward Feigenbaum") and [Julian Feldman](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Julian_Feldman&action=edit&redlink=1 "Julian Feldman (page does not exist)") published _Computers and Thought_, the first collection of articles about artificial intelligence.[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-68)[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-69)[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-70)[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-71) |
| [Leonard Uhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonard_Uhr "Leonard Uhr") and Charles Vossler published "A Pattern Recognition Program That Generates, Evaluates, and Adjusts Its Own Operators", which described one of the first machine learning programs that could adaptively acquire and modify features and thereby overcome the limitations of simple perceptrons of [Rosenblatt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Rosenblatt "Frank Rosenblatt"). |
| 1964 | Danny Bobrow's dissertation at MIT (technical report #1 from MIT's AI group, [Project MAC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_MAC "Project MAC")), shows that computers can understand natural language well enough to solve [algebra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebra "Algebra")[word problems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_problem_(mathematics_education) "Word problem (mathematics education)") correctly. |
| [Bertram Raphael](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertram_Raphael "Bertram Raphael")'s MIT dissertation on the SIR program demonstrates the power of a logical representation of knowledge for question-answering systems. |
| 1965 | [Alexey Ivakhnenko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexey_Ivakhnenko "Alexey Ivakhnenko") and Valentin Lapa developed the first [deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning") algorithm for [multilayer perceptrons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron "Multilayer perceptron") in [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union").[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-ivak1965-72)[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-ivak1967-73)[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) |
| [Lotfi A. Zadeh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotfi_A._Zadeh "Lotfi A. Zadeh") at U.C. Berkeley publishes his first paper introducing [fuzzy logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic "Fuzzy logic"), "Fuzzy Sets" (Information and Control 8: 338–353). |
| J. Alan Robinson invented a mechanical [proof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_proof "Mathematical proof") procedure, the Resolution Method, which allowed programs to work efficiently with formal logic as a representation language. |
| [Joseph Weizenbaum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Weizenbaum "Joseph Weizenbaum") (MIT) built [ELIZA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ELIZA "ELIZA"), an [interactive program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactive_program "Interactive program") that carries on a dialogue in [English language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language "English language") on any topic. It was a popular toy at AI centers on the [ARPANET](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARPANET "ARPANET") when a version that "simulated" the dialogue of a [psychotherapist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychotherapy "Psychotherapy") was programmed. |
| [Edward Feigenbaum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Feigenbaum "Edward Feigenbaum") initiated [Dendral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dendral "Dendral"), a ten-year effort to develop software to deduce the molecular structure of organic compounds using scientific instrument data. It was the first [expert system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expert_system "Expert system"). |
| 1966 | Ross Quillian (PhD dissertation, Carnegie Inst. of Technology, now CMU) demonstrated [semantic nets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_network "Semantic network"). |
| Machine Intelligence[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-74) workshop at Edinburgh – the first of an influential annual series organized by [Donald Michie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Michie "Donald Michie") and others. |
| Negative report on machine translation kills much work in [natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing "Natural language processing") (NLP) for many years. |
| [Dendral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dendral "Dendral") program (Edward Feigenbaum, [Joshua Lederberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_Lederberg "Joshua Lederberg"), Bruce Buchanan, Georgia Sutherland at [Stanford University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_University "Stanford University")) demonstrated to interpret mass spectra of organic chemical compounds. First successful knowledge-based program for scientific reasoning. |
| 1967 | [Shun'ichi Amari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shun%27ichi_Amari "Shun'ichi Amari") was the first to use [stochastic gradient descent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent "Stochastic gradient descent") for [deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning") in [multilayer perceptrons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron "Multilayer perceptron").[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-Amari1967-75) In computer experiments conducted by his student Saito, a five layer MLP with two modifiable layers learned useful [internal representations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_representation "Knowledge representation") to classify non-linearily separable pattern classes.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) |
| 1968 | [Joel Moses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joel_Moses "Joel Moses") (PhD work at MIT) demonstrated the power of [symbolic reasoning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_mathematics "Symbolic mathematics") for integration problems in the [Macsyma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macsyma "Macsyma") program. First successful knowledge-based program in [mathematics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics "Mathematics"). |
| [Richard Greenblatt (programmer)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Greenblatt_(programmer) "Richard Greenblatt (programmer)") at MIT built a knowledge-based [chess-playing program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_chess "Computer chess"), [Mac Hack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mac_Hack "Mac Hack"), that was good enough to achieve a class-C rating in tournament play. |
| Wallace and Boulton's program, Snob (Comp.J. 11(2) 1968), for unsupervised classification (clustering) uses the Bayesian [minimum message length](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_message_length "Minimum message length") criterion, a mathematical realisation of [Occam's razor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occam%27s_razor "Occam's razor"). |
| 1969 | [Stanford Research Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SRI_International "SRI International") (SRI): [Shakey the robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shakey_the_robot "Shakey the robot"), demonstrated combining [animal locomotion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_locomotion "Animal locomotion"), [perception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perception "Perception") and [problem solving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Problem_solving "Problem solving"). |
| [Roger Schank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Schank "Roger Schank") (Stanford) defined [conceptual](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concept "Concept") dependency model for [natural language understanding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_understanding "Natural language understanding"). Later developed (in PhD dissertations at [Yale University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yale_University "Yale University")) for use in story understanding by [Robert Wilensky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Wilensky "Robert Wilensky") and Wendy Lehnert, and for use in understanding memory by Janet Kolodner. |
| Yorick Wilks (Stanford) developed the semantic coherence view of language called Preference Semantics, embodied in the first semantics-driven machine translation program, and the basis of many PhD dissertations since such as Bran Boguraev and David Carter at Cambridge. |
| First International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence ([IJCAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IJCAI "IJCAI")) held at Stanford. |
| Marvin Minsky and [Seymour Papert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seymour_Papert "Seymour Papert") publish _[Perceptrons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptrons\_(book) "Perceptrons (book)")_, demonstrating previously unrecognized limits of this feed-forward two-layered structure. This book is considered by some to mark the beginning of the [AI winter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_winter "AI winter") of the 1970s, a failure of confidence and funding for AI. However, by the time the book came out, methods for training [multilayer perceptrons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptrons "Multilayer perceptrons") by [deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning") were already known ([Alexey Ivakhnenko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexey_Ivakhnenko "Alexey Ivakhnenko") and Valentin Lapa, 1965; [Shun'ichi Amari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shun%27ichi_Amari "Shun'ichi Amari"), 1967).[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) Significant progress in the field continued (see below). |
| McCarthy and Hayes started the discussion about the [frame problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frame_problem "Frame problem") with their essay, "Some Philosophical Problems from the Standpoint of Artificial Intelligence". |

### 1970s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 1970s")]

[![Image 8: icon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/60px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)This section **needs additional citations for [verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:EditPage/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence "Special:EditPage/Timeline of artificial intelligence") by [adding citations to reliable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners") in this section. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed._(March 2007)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Maintenance\_template\_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| Early 1970s | Jane Robinson and Don Walker established an influential [Natural Language Processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_Language_Processing "Natural Language Processing") group at SRI.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-76) |
| 1970 | [Seppo Linnainmaa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seppo_Linnainmaa "Seppo Linnainmaa") publishes the reverse mode of [automatic differentiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_differentiation "Automatic differentiation"). This method became later known as [backpropagation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation"), and is heavily used to train [artificial neural networks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_neural_networks "Artificial neural networks").[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-77) |
| Jaime Carbonell (Sr.) developed SCHOLAR, an interactive program for [computer-assisted instruction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-assisted_instruction "Computer-assisted instruction") based on semantic nets as the representation of knowledge. |
| Bill Woods described Augmented Transition Networks (ATNs) as a representation for natural language understanding. |
| [Patrick Winston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patrick_Winston "Patrick Winston")'s PhD program, ARCH, at MIT, learned concepts from examples in the world of children's blocks. |
| 1971 | [Terry Winograd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Winograd "Terry Winograd")'s PhD thesis ([MIT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT "MIT")) demonstrated the ability of computers to understand English sentences in a restricted world of children's blocks, in a coupling of his language understanding program, [SHRDLU](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHRDLU "SHRDLU"), with a robot arm that carried out instructions typed in English. |
| Work on the Boyer-Moore theorem prover started in [Edinburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh").[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-78) |
| 1972 | [Prolog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prolog "Prolog") programming language developed by [Alain Colmerauer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Colmerauer "Alain Colmerauer"). |
| Earl Sacerdoti developed one of the first hierarchical planning programs, ABSTRIPS. |
| 1973 | The Assembly Robotics Group at [University of Edinburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh "University of Edinburgh") builds Freddy Robot, capable of using [visual perception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_perception "Visual perception") to locate and assemble models. (See [Edinburgh _Freddy_ Assembly Robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freddy_II "Freddy II"): a versatile computer-controlled assembly system.) |
| The [Lighthill report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lighthill_report "Lighthill report") gives a largely negative verdict on AI research in Great Britain and forms the basis for the decision by the British government to discontinue support for AI research in all but two universities. |
| 1974 | [Ted Shortliffe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_H._Shortliffe "Edward H. Shortliffe")'s PhD dissertation on the [MYCIN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MYCIN "MYCIN") program (Stanford) demonstrated a very practical rule-based approach to medical diagnoses, even in the presence of uncertainty. While it borrowed from DENDRAL, its own contributions strongly influenced the future of [expert system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expert_system "Expert system") development, especially commercial systems. |
| 1975 | Earl Sacerdoti developed techniques of [partial-order planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial-order_planning "Partial-order planning") in his NOAH system, replacing the previous paradigm of search among state space descriptions. NOAH was applied at SRI International to interactively diagnose and repair electromechanical systems. |
| [Austin Tate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin_Tate "Austin Tate") developed the Nonlin hierarchical planning system, able to search a space of [partial plans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_plan "Partial plan") characterised as alternative approaches to the underlying goal structure of the plan. |
| Marvin Minsky published his widely read and influential article on [Frames](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frame_problem "Frame problem") as a representation of knowledge, in which many ideas about [schemas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schema_(psychology) "Schema (psychology)") and [semantic links](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_link "Semantic link") are brought together. |
| The Meta-Dendral learning program produced new results in [chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry") (some rules of [mass spectrometry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_spectrometry "Mass spectrometry")), the first scientific discoveries by a computer to be published in a refereed journal. |
| Mid-1970s | [Barbara Grosz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Grosz "Barbara Grosz") (SRI) established limits to traditional AI approaches to discourse modeling. Subsequent work by Grosz, [Bonnie Webber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonnie_Webber "Bonnie Webber") and [Candace Sidner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candace_Sidner "Candace Sidner") developed the notion of "centering", used in establishing focus of [discourse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discourse "Discourse") and anaphoric references in [Natural language processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing "Natural language processing"). |
| [David Marr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Marr_(psychologist) "David Marr (psychologist)") and [MIT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT "MIT") colleagues describe the "primal sketch" and its role in [visual perception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_perception "Visual perception"). |
| 1976 | [Douglas Lenat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Lenat "Douglas Lenat")'s [AM program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_Mathematician "Automated Mathematician") (Stanford PhD dissertation) demonstrated the discovery model (loosely guided search for interesting conjectures). |
| Randall Davis demonstrated the power of meta-level reasoning in his PhD dissertation at Stanford. |
| Stevo Bozinovski and Ante Fulgosi introduced transfer learning method in artificial intelligence, based on the psychology of learning.[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-79)[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-80) |
| 1978 | [Tom Mitchell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_M._Mitchell "Tom M. Mitchell"), at Stanford, invented the concept of [Version spaces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Version_space "Version space") for describing the [search space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candidate_solution "Candidate solution") of a concept formation program. |
| [Herbert A. Simon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon "Herbert A. Simon") wins the [Nobel Prize in Economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Sweden_Prize_in_Economic_Sciences_in_Memory_of_Alfred_Nobel "Bank of Sweden Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel") for his theory of [bounded rationality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_rationality "Bounded rationality"), one of the cornerstones of AI known as "[satisficing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisficing "Satisficing")". |
| The MOLGEN program, written at [Stanford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stamford,_Connecticut "Stamford, Connecticut") by Mark Stefik and Peter Friedland, demonstrated that an [object-oriented programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming "Object-oriented programming") representation of knowledge can be used to plan gene-[cloning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloning "Cloning") experiments. |
| 1979 | Bill VanMelle's PhD dissertation at Stanford demonstrated the generality of [MYCIN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MYCIN "MYCIN")'s representation of knowledge and style of reasoning in his [EMYCIN](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=EMYCIN&action=edit&redlink=1 "EMYCIN (page does not exist)") program, the model for many commercial expert system "shells". |
| Jack Myers and Harry Pople at [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh") developed INTERNIST, a knowledge-based medical diagnosis program based on Dr. Myers' [clinical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinic "Clinic") knowledge. |
| [Cordell Green](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cordell_Green "Cordell Green"), David Barstow, [Elaine Kant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaine_Kant "Elaine Kant") and others at Stanford demonstrated the CHI system for [automatic programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_programming "Automatic programming"). |
| The Stanford Cart, built by [Hans Moravec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Moravec "Hans Moravec"), becomes the first computer-controlled, [autonomous vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot "Autonomous robot") when it successfully traverses a chair-filled room and circumnavigates the [Stanford AI Lab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_AI_Lab "Stanford AI Lab"). |
| BKG, a backgammon program written by [Hans Berliner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Berliner "Hans Berliner") at [CMU](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University "Carnegie Mellon University"), defeats the reigning world champion (in part via luck). |
| Drew McDermott and Jon Doyle at [MIT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT "MIT"), and John McCarthy at Stanford, begin publishing work on [non-monotonic logics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-monotonic_logic "Non-monotonic logic") and formal aspects of truth maintenance. |
| Late 1970s | Stanford's SUMEX-AIM resource, headed by Ed Feigenbaum and Joshua Lederberg, demonstrates the power of the ARPAnet for scientific collaboration. |

### 1980s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: 1980s")]

[![Image 9: icon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/60px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)This section **needs additional citations for [verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:EditPage/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence "Special:EditPage/Timeline of artificial intelligence") by [adding citations to reliable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners") in this section. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed._(March 2007)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Maintenance\_template\_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 1980s | [Lisp machines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisp_machine "Lisp machine") developed and marketed. First [expert system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expert_system "Expert system") shells and commercial applications. |
| 1980 | First National Conference of the [American Association for Artificial Intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Association_for_Artificial_Intelligence "American Association for Artificial Intelligence") (AAAI) held at Stanford. |
| 1981 | [Danny Hillis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danny_Hillis "Danny Hillis") designs the connection machine, which utilizes [parallel computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_computing "Parallel computing") to bring new power to AI, and to computation in general. (Later founds [Thinking Machines Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thinking_Machines_Corporation "Thinking Machines Corporation")) |
| Stevo Bozinovski and Charles Anderson carried out the first concurrent programming (task parallelism) in neural network research. A program, "CAA Controller," written and executed by Bozinovski, interacts with the program "Inverted Pendulum Dynamics" written and executed by Anderson, using VAX/VMS mailboxes as a way of inter-program communication. The CAA controller learns to balance the simulated inverted pendulum.[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-81)[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-82)[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-83) |
| 1982 | The [Fifth Generation Computer Systems project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fifth_Generation_Computer_Systems_project "Fifth Generation Computer Systems project") (FGCS), an initiative by Japan's [Ministry of International Trade and Industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_International_Trade_and_Industry "Ministry of International Trade and Industry"), begun in 1982, to create a "fifth generation computer" (see history of computing hardware) which was supposed to perform many calculations utilizing massive parallelism. |
| 1983 | John Laird and Paul Rosenbloom, working with [Allen Newell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Newell "Allen Newell"), complete CMU dissertations on [Soar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soar_(cognitive_architecture) "Soar (cognitive architecture)") (program). |
| [James F. Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_F._Allen_(computer_scientist) "James F. Allen (computer scientist)") invents the Interval Calculus, the first widely used formalization of temporal events. |
| Mid-1980s | Neural Networks become widely used with the [Backpropagation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation")[algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm "Algorithm"), also known as the reverse mode of [automatic differentiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_differentiation "Automatic differentiation") published by [Seppo Linnainmaa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seppo_Linnainmaa "Seppo Linnainmaa") in 1970 and applied to neural networks by [Paul Werbos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Werbos "Paul Werbos"). |
| 1985 | The autonomous drawing program, [AARON](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AARON "AARON"), created by [Harold Cohen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Cohen_(artist) "Harold Cohen (artist)"), is demonstrated at the AAAI National Conference (based on more than a decade of work, and with subsequent work showing major developments). |
| 1986 | The team of [Ernst Dickmanns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Dickmanns "Ernst Dickmanns") at [Bundeswehr University of Munich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bundeswehr_University_of_Munich "Bundeswehr University of Munich") builds the first robot cars, driving up to 55 mph on empty streets. |
| [Barbara Grosz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Grosz "Barbara Grosz") and [Candace Sidner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candace_Sidner "Candace Sidner") create the first computation model of [discourse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discourse "Discourse"), establishing the field of research.[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-84) |
| 1987 | Marvin Minsky published _[The Society of Mind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Society\_of\_Mind "The Society of Mind")_, a theoretical description of the mind as a collection of cooperating [agents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent "Intelligent agent"). He had been lecturing on the idea for years before the book came out (cf. Doyle 1983).[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-Henderson2007-85) |
| Around the same time, [Rodney Brooks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rodney_Brooks "Rodney Brooks") introduced the [subsumption architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsumption_architecture "Subsumption architecture") and [behavior-based robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics "Behavior-based robotics") as a more minimalist modular model of natural intelligence; [Nouvelle AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nouvelle_AI "Nouvelle AI"). |
| Commercial launch of generation 2.0 of Alacrity by Alacritous Inc./Allstar Advice Inc. Toronto, the first commercial strategic and managerial advisory system. The system was based upon a forward-chaining, self-developed expert system with 3,000 rules about the evolution of markets and competitive strategies and co-authored by Alistair Davidson and Mary Chung, founders of the firm with the underlying engine developed by Paul Tarvydas. The Alacrity system also included a small financial expert system that interpreted financial statements and models.[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-86) |
| 1989 | The development of [metal–oxide–semiconductor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metal%E2%80%93oxide%E2%80%93semiconductor "Metal–oxide–semiconductor") (MOS) [Very-large-scale integration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Very-large-scale_integration "Very-large-scale integration") (VLSI), in the form of [complementary MOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMOS "CMOS") (CMOS) technology, enabled the development of practical [artificial neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning) "Neural network (machine learning)") (ANN) technology in the 1980s. A landmark publication in the field was the 1989 book _Analog VLSI Implementation of Neural Systems_ by Carver A. Mead and Mohammed Ismail.[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-Mead-87) |
| Dean Pomerleau at CMU created ALVINN (An Autonomous Land Vehicle in a Neural Network), which was used in the [Navlab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navlab "Navlab") program. |

### 1990s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: 1990s")]

[![Image 10: icon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/60px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)This section **needs additional citations for [verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:EditPage/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence "Special:EditPage/Timeline of artificial intelligence") by [adding citations to reliable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners") in this section. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed._(March 2007)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Maintenance\_template\_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 1990s | Major advances in all areas of AI, with significant demonstrations in machine learning, [intelligent tutoring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_assisted_instruction "Computer assisted instruction"), case-based reasoning, multi-agent planning, [scheduling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheduling_(computing) "Scheduling (computing)"), uncertain reasoning, [data mining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_mining "Data mining"), natural language understanding and translation, vision, [virtual reality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality "Virtual reality"), games, and other topics. |
| Early 1990s | [TD-Gammon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TD-Gammon "TD-Gammon"), a [backgammon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backgammon "Backgammon") program written by Gerry Tesauro, demonstrates that [reinforcement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement "Reinforcement") (learning) is powerful enough to create a championship-level game-playing program by competing favorably with world-class players. |
| 1991 | [DART](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_Analysis_and_Replanning_Tool "Dynamic Analysis and Replanning Tool") scheduling application deployed in the first [Gulf War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") paid back [DARPA's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA "DARPA") investment of 30 years in AI research.[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-88) |
| 1992 | [Carol Stoker](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carol_Stoker&action=edit&redlink=1 "Carol Stoker (page does not exist)") and NASA Ames robotics team explore marine life in Antarctica with an undersea robot [Telepresence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telepresence "Telepresence")[ROV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remotely_Operated_Vehicle "Remotely Operated Vehicle") operated from the ice near McMurdo Bay, Antarctica and remotely via satellite link from Moffett Field, California.[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-89) |
| 1993 | [Ian Horswill](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ian_Horswill&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ian Horswill (page does not exist)") extended [behavior-based robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics "Behavior-based robotics") by creating Polly, the first robot to navigate using [vision](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision "Computer vision") and operate at animal-like speeds (1 meter/second). |
| [Rodney Brooks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rodney_Brooks "Rodney Brooks"), [Lynn Andrea Stein](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lynn_Andrea_Stein&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lynn Andrea Stein (page does not exist)") and [Cynthia Breazeal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cynthia_Breazeal "Cynthia Breazeal") started the widely publicized [MIT Cog project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT_Cog_project "MIT Cog project") with numerous collaborators, in an attempt to build a [humanoid robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanoid_robot "Humanoid robot") child in just five years. |
| ISX corporation wins "DARPA contractor of the year"[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-90) for the [Dynamic Analysis and Replanning Tool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_Analysis_and_Replanning_Tool "Dynamic Analysis and Replanning Tool") (DART), which reportedly repaid the US government's entire investment in AI research since the 1950s.[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-91) |
| 1994 | [Lotfi A. Zadeh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotfi_A._Zadeh "Lotfi A. Zadeh") at U.C. Berkeley creates "[soft computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_computing "Soft computing")"[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-92) and builds a world network of research with a fusion of neural science and [neural net](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_net "Neural net") systems, [fuzzy set](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_set "Fuzzy set") theory and [fuzzy systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_systems "Fuzzy systems"), evolutionary algorithms, [genetic programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_programming "Genetic programming"), and [chaos theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaos_theory "Chaos theory") and chaotic systems ("Fuzzy Logic, Neural Networks, and Soft Computing", _Communications of the ACM_, March 1994, Vol. 37 No. 3, pages 77–84). |
| With passengers on board, the twin robot cars [VaMP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VaMP "VaMP") and VITA-2 of [Ernst Dickmanns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Dickmanns "Ernst Dickmanns") and [Daimler-Benz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daimler-Benz "Daimler-Benz") drive more than one thousand kilometers on a Paris three-lane highway in standard heavy traffic at speeds up to 130 km/h. They demonstrate autonomous driving in free lanes, convoy driving, and lane changes left and right with autonomous passing of other cars. |
| [English draughts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_draughts "English draughts") ([checkers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checkers_(game) "Checkers (game)")) world champion [Tinsley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marion_Tinsley "Marion Tinsley") resigned a match against computer program [Chinook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinook_(draughts_player) "Chinook (draughts player)"). Chinook defeated 2nd-highest-rated player, [Lafferty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Lafferty "Don Lafferty"). Chinook won the USA National Tournament by the widest margin ever. |
| [Cindy Mason](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cindy_Mason&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cindy Mason (page does not exist)") at [NASA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA "NASA") organizes the First [AAAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AAAI "AAAI") Workshop on AI and the Environment.[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-93) |
| 1995 | [Cindy Mason](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cindy_Mason&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cindy Mason (page does not exist)") at [NASA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA "NASA") organizes the First International [IJCAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IJCAI "IJCAI") Workshop on AI and the Environment.[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-94) |
| "No Hands Across America": A semi-autonomous car drove coast-to-coast across the United States with computer-controlled steering for 2,797 miles (4,501 km) of the 2,849 miles (4,585 km). The throttle and brakes were controlled by a human driver.[[93]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-95)[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-96) |
| One of [Ernst Dickmanns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Dickmanns "Ernst Dickmanns")' robot cars (with robot-controlled throttle and brakes) drove more than 1000 miles from [Munich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munich "Munich") to [Copenhagen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen") and back, in traffic, at up to 120 mph, occasionally executing maneuvers to pass other cars (only in a few critical situations a safety driver took over). Active vision was used to deal with rapidly changing street scenes. |
| 1996 | [Steve Grand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Grand_(roboticist) "Steve Grand (roboticist)"), roboticist and computer scientist, develops and releases [_Creatures_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creatures_(video_game_series) "Creatures (video game series)"), a popular simulation of artificial life-forms with simulated biochemistry, neurology with learning algorithms and inheritable digital DNA. |
| 1997 | The [Deep Blue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Deep_Blue "IBM Deep Blue") chess machine ([IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM")) defeats the (then) world [chess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chess "Chess") champion, [Garry Kasparov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garry_Kasparov "Garry Kasparov"). |
| First official [RoboCup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboCup "RoboCup") football (soccer) match featuring table-top matches with 40 teams of interacting robots and over 5000 spectators. |
| Computer [Othello](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reversi "Reversi") program [Logistello](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistello "Logistello") defeated the world champion, Takeshi Murakami with a score of 6–0. |
| [Long short-term memory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_short-term_memory "Long short-term memory") (LSTM) was published in Neural Computation by [Sepp Hochreiter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sepp_Hochreiter "Sepp Hochreiter") and [Juergen Schmidhuber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juergen_Schmidhuber "Juergen Schmidhuber").[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-lstm1997-97) |
| 1998 | [Tiger Electronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiger_Electronics "Tiger Electronics")' [Furby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Furby "Furby") is released, and becomes the first successful attempt at producing a type of AI designated for a [domestic environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_robot "Domestic robot"). |
| [Tim Berners-Lee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee "Tim Berners-Lee") published his [Semantic Web Road map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web "Semantic Web") paper.[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-98) |
| [Ulises Cortés](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ulises_Cort%C3%A9s&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ulises Cortés (page does not exist)") and [Miquel Sànchez-Marrè](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Miquel_S%C3%A0nchez-Marr%C3%A8&action=edit&redlink=1 "Miquel Sànchez-Marrè (page does not exist)") organize the first Environment and AI Workshop in Europe [ECAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Conference_on_Artificial_Intelligence "European Conference on Artificial Intelligence"), "Binding Environmental Sciences and Artificial Intelligence".[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-99)[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-100) |
| [Leslie P. Kaelbling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leslie_P._Kaelbling "Leslie P. Kaelbling"), [Michael L. Littman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_L._Littman "Michael L. Littman"), and Anthony Cassandra introduce [POMDPs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partially_observable_Markov_decision_process "Partially observable Markov decision process") and a scalable method for solving them to the AI community, jumpstarting widespread use in robotics and [automated planning and scheduling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling "Automated planning and scheduling")[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-101) |
| 1999 | [Sony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony "Sony") introduces an improved domestic robot similar to a Furby, the [AIBO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AIBO "AIBO") becomes one of the first artificially intelligent "pets" that is also [autonomous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot "Autonomous robot"). |
| Late 1990s | [Web crawlers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_crawler "Web crawler") and other AI-based [information extraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_extraction "Information extraction") programs become essential in widespread use of the [World Wide Web](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web"). |
| Demonstration of an Intelligent room and Emotional Agents at [MIT's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology "Massachusetts Institute of Technology") AI Lab. |
| Initiation of work on the [Oxygen architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Oxygen "Project Oxygen"), which connects mobile and stationary computers in an adaptive [network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network"). |

21st century
------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: 21st century")]

### 2000s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: 2000s")]

[![Image 11: icon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/60px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)This section **needs additional citations for [verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**.
