Unsourced material may be challenged and removed._(March 2007)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Maintenance\_template\_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 2000 | Interactive robopets ("[smart toys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_toy "Smart toy")") become commercially available, realizing the vision of the 18th-century novelty toy makers. |
| [Cynthia Breazeal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cynthia_Breazeal "Cynthia Breazeal") at MIT publishes her dissertation on Sociable machines, describing [Kismet (robot)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kismet_(robot) "Kismet (robot)"), with a face that expresses [emotions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion "Emotion"). |
| The [Nomad robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nomad_rover "Nomad rover") explores remote regions of Antarctica looking for meteorite samples. |
| 2002 | [iRobot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRobot "IRobot")'s [Roomba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roomba "Roomba") autonomously vacuums the floor while navigating and avoiding obstacles. |
| [Wolfbot Future](https://web.archive.org/web/20020112171758/http://www.wolfbot.com/future.htm) describes artificial intelligent agents based on XML with a distributed ontology. |
| 2004 | OWL [Web Ontology Language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_Ontology_Language "Web Ontology Language") W3C Recommendation (10 February 2004). |
| [DARPA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defense_Advanced_Research_Projects_Agency "Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency") introduces the [DARPA Grand Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Grand_Challenge "DARPA Grand Challenge"), requiring competitors to produce autonomous vehicles for prize money. |
| [NASA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA "NASA")'s robotic exploration rovers [Spirit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirit_rover "Spirit rover") and [Opportunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opportunity_rover "Opportunity rover") autonomously navigate the surface of [Mars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars "Mars"). |
| 2005 | [Honda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honda "Honda")'s [ASIMO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASIMO "ASIMO") robot, an artificially intelligent humanoid robot, can walk as fast as a human, delivering [trays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tray "Tray") to customers in restaurant settings. |
| [Recommendation technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recommender_system "Recommender system") based on tracking web activity or media usage brings AI to marketing. See [TiVo Suggestions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TiVo "TiVo"). |
| [Blue Brain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Brain "Blue Brain") is born, a project to simulate the brain at molecular detail.[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-102) |
| 2006 | The Dartmouth Artificial Intelligence Conference: The Next 50 Years ([AI@50](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI@50 "AI@50")) (14–16 July 2006) |
| 2007 | [Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, B– Biology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phil._Trans._R._Soc._B "Phil. Trans. R. Soc. B"), one of the world's oldest scientific journals, puts out a special issue on using AI to understand biological intelligence, titled _Models of Natural [Action Selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action\_selection "Action selection")_[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-103) |
| [Checkers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checkers "Checkers") is [solved](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solved_game "Solved game") by a team of researchers at the [University of Alberta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Alberta "University of Alberta"). |
| [DARPA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA "DARPA") launches the [Urban Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Grand_Challenge#2007_Urban_Challenge "DARPA Grand Challenge") for [autonomous cars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_cars "Autonomous cars") to obey traffic rules and operate in an urban environment. |
| 2008 | Cynthia Mason at Stanford presents her idea on Artificial Compassionate Intelligence, in her paper on "Giving Robots Compassion".[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-104) |
| 2009 | An [LSTM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LSTM "LSTM") trained by [connectionist temporal classification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connectionist_temporal_classification "Connectionist temporal classification")[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-graves2006-105) was the first [recurrent neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network "Recurrent neural network") to win [pattern recognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattern_recognition "Pattern recognition") contests, winning three competitions in connected [handwriting recognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handwriting_recognition "Handwriting recognition").[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-106)[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidhuber2022-9) |
| 2009 | [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google") builds an autonomous car.[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-107) |

### 2010s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: 2010s")]

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 2010 | [Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") launched Kinect for Xbox 360, the first gaming device to track human body movement, using just a 3D camera and infrared detection, enabling users to play their Xbox 360 wirelessly. The award-winning machine learning for human motion capture technology for this device was developed by the [Computer Vision group](http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/groups/vision/default.aspx) at [Microsoft Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Research#Laboratories "Microsoft Research"), Cambridge.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-108)[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-109) |
| 2011 | [Mary Lou Maher](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mary_Lou_Maher&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mary Lou Maher (page does not exist)") and [Doug Fisher](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Doug_Fisher_(academic)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Doug Fisher (academic) (page does not exist)") organize the First [AAAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AAAI "AAAI") Workshop on AI and Sustainability.[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-110) |
| [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM")'s [Watson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Watson "IBM Watson") computer defeated [television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television "Television")[game show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_show "Game show")_[Jeopardy!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeopardy! "Jeopardy!")_ champions [Rutter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Rutter "Brad Rutter") and [Jennings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ken_Jennings "Ken Jennings"). |
| 2011–2014 | [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.")'s [Siri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siri "Siri") (2011), [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google")'s [Google Now](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Now "Google Now") (2012) and [Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft")'s [Cortana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cortana_(virtual_assistant) "Cortana (virtual assistant)") (2014) are [smartphone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smartphone "Smartphone")[apps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_software "Application software") that use [natural language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language "Natural language") to answer questions, make recommendations and perform actions. |
| 2012 | [AlexNet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlexNet "AlexNet"), a [deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning") model developed by [Alex Krizhevsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Krizhevsky "Alex Krizhevsky"), wins the [ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ImageNet_Large_Scale_Visual_Recognition_Challenge "ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge") with half as many errors as the second-place winner.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-111) This is a turning point in the history of AI; over the next few years, dozens of other approaches to image recognition were abandoned in favor of [deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning").[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWong2023-112) Krizhevsky is among the first to use GPU chips to train a deep learning network.[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChristian202025-113) |
| 2013 | [Robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot "Robot") HRP-2 built by SCHAFT Inc of [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan "Japan"), a subsidiary of [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google"), defeats 15 teams to win [DARPA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA "DARPA")'s [Robotics Challenge Trials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Robotics_Challenge#Trials "DARPA Robotics Challenge"). HRP-2 scored 27 out of 32 points in the eight tasks needed in disaster response. Tasks are driving a vehicle, walking over debris, climbing a ladder, removing debris, walking through doors, cutting through a wall, closing valves and connecting a hose.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-114) |
| [NEIL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Never-Ending_Language_Learning "Never-Ending Language Learning"), the Never-Ending Image Learner, is released at [Carnegie Mellon University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University "Carnegie Mellon University") to constantly compare and analyze relationships between different images.[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-115) |
| 2015 | Two techniques were developed concurrently to train very deep networks: [highway network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Highway_network "Highway network"),[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-highway20152-116) and the [residual neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Residual_neural_network "Residual neural network") (ResNet).[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-resnet20152-117) They allowed over 1000-layers-deep networks to be trained. |
| In January 2015, [Stephen Hawking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Hawking "Stephen Hawking"), [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk"), and dozens of artificial intelligence experts signed an [open letter on artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_letter_on_artificial_intelligence_(2015) "Open letter on artificial intelligence (2015)") calling for research on the societal impacts of AI.[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-telegraph-118)[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-119) |
| In July 2015, an open letter to ban the development and use of autonomous weapons was signed by [Hawking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Hawking "Stephen Hawking"), [Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk"), [Wozniak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Wozniak "Steve Wozniak") and 3,000 researchers in AI and robotics.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-120) |
| [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google")[DeepMind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind")'s [AlphaGo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlphaGo "AlphaGo") (version: Fan)[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-:0-121) defeated three-time European Go champion 2 dan professional [Fan Hui](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fan_Hui "Fan Hui") by 5 games to 0.[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-122) |
| 2016 | [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google")[DeepMind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind")'s [AlphaGo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlphaGo "AlphaGo") (version: Lee)[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-:0-121) defeated [Lee Sedol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Sedol "Lee Sedol") 4–1. Lee Sedol is a 9-dan professional Korean [Go](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Go_(game) "Go (game)") champion who won 27 major tournaments from 2002 to 2016.[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-123) |
| 2017 | [Asilomar Conference on Beneficial AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asilomar_Conference_on_Beneficial_AI "Asilomar Conference on Beneficial AI") was held, to discuss [AI ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_ethics "AI ethics") and how to bring about [beneficial AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beneficial_AI "Beneficial AI") while avoiding the [existential risk from artificial general intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existential_risk_from_artificial_general_intelligence "Existential risk from artificial general intelligence"). |
| Deepstack[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-124) is the first published algorithm to beat human players in imperfect information games, as shown with statistical significance on heads-up no-limit [poker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poker "Poker"). Soon after, the poker AI [Libratus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libratus "Libratus") by a different research group individually defeated each of its four-human opponents—among the best players in the world—at an exceptionally high aggregated winrate, over a statistically significant sample.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-125) In contrast to Chess and Go, Poker is an [imperfect information](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperfect_information "Imperfect information") game.[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-the_Guardian-126) |
| In May 2017, [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google")[DeepMind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind")'s [AlphaGo (version: Master)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_(software) "Master (software)") beat [Ke Jie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ke_Jie "Ke Jie"), who at the time continuously held the world No. 1 ranking for two years,[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-127)[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-128) winning each game in a [three-game match](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlphaGo_versus_Ke_Jie "AlphaGo versus Ke Jie") during the [Future of Go Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Future_of_Go_Summit "Future of Go Summit").[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-wuzhensecond-129)[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-130) |
| A [propositional logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_logic "Propositional logic")[boolean satisfiability problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_problem "Boolean satisfiability problem") (SAT) solver proves a long-standing mathematical conjecture on [Pythagorean triples](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pythagorean_triples "Pythagorean triples") over the set of integers. The initial proof, 200TB long, was checked by two independent certified automatic proof checkers.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-131) |
| An [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI")[bot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_bot "Video game bot") using machine learning played at [The International 2017](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_International_2017 "The International 2017")_[Dota 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dota\_2 "Dota 2")_ tournament in August 2017. It won during a [1v1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1v1 "1v1") demonstration game against professional _Dota 2_ player [Dendi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dendi_(Dota_player) "Dendi (Dota player)").[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-132) |
| [Google Lens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Lens "Google Lens") image analysis and comparison tool released in October 2017, associates millions of landscapes, artworks, products and species to their text description. |
| Google DeepMind revealed that AlphaGo Zero—an improved version of AlphaGo—displayed significant performance gains while using far fewer [tensor processing units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tensor_processing_unit "Tensor processing unit") (as compared to AlphaGo Lee; it used the same amount of TPUs as AlphaGo Master).[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-:0-121) Unlike previous versions, which learned the game by observing millions of human moves, AlphaGo Zero learned by playing only against itself. The system then defeated AlphaGo Lee 100 games to zero, and defeated AlphaGo Master 89 to 11.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-:0-121) Although unsupervised learning is a step forward, much has yet to be learned about general intelligence.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-133) AlphaZero masters chess in four hours, defeating the best chess engine, StockFish 8. AlphaZero won 28 out of 100 games, and the remaining 72 games ended in a draw. |
| [Transformer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformer_(machine_learning_model) "Transformer (machine learning model)") architecture was invented, which led to new kinds of [large language models](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model "Large language model") such as [BERT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BERT_(language_model) "BERT (language model)") by Google, followed by the [generative pre-trained transformer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_pre-trained_transformer "Generative pre-trained transformer") type of model introduced by OpenAI. |
| 2018 | Alibaba language processing AI outscores top humans at a Stanford University reading and comprehension test, scoring 82.44 against 82.304 on a set of 100,000 questions.[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-134) |
| The European Lab for Learning and Intelligent Systems (_aka_ Ellis) proposed as a pan-European competitor to American AI efforts, to stave off a [brain drain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain-drain "Brain-drain") of talent, along the lines of [CERN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CERN "CERN") after World War II.[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-135) |
| Announcement of [Google Duplex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Duplex "Google Duplex"), a service to allow an AI assistant to book appointments over the phone. The _[Los Angeles Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los\_Angeles\_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ judges the AI's voice to be a "nearly flawless" imitation of human-sounding speech.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-136) |
| 2019 | DeepMind's AlphaStar reaches Grandmaster level at _StarCraft II_, outperforming 99.8 percent of human players.[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-137) |

### 2020s

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: 2020s")]

See also: [2020s in computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020s_in_computing "2020s in computing")

![Image 12](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/60px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png)This section needs to be **updated**. Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information._(September 2023)_
[![Image 13](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/20250202_%22AI%22_%28search_term%29_on_Google_Trends.svg/250px-20250202_%22AI%22_%28search_term%29_on_Google_Trends.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:20250202_%22AI%22_(search_term)_on_Google_Trends.svg)

The number of the public's Google searches for the term "AI" began to accelerate in 2022.

| Date | Development |
| --- | --- |
| 2020 | In February 2020, Microsoft introduces its Turing Natural Language Generation (T-NLG), which is the "largest language model ever published at 17 billion parameters".[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-Wired_Sterling_20200213-138) |
| In November 2020, [AlphaFold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlphaFold "AlphaFold") 2 by DeepMind, a model that performs [predictions of protein structure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein_structure_prediction "Protein structure prediction"), wins the [CASP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CASP "CASP") competition.[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-139) |
| [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI") introduces [GPT-3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3 "GPT-3"), a state-of-the-art autoregressive language model that uses [deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning") to produce a variety of computer codes, poetry and other language tasks exceptionally similar, and almost indistinguishable from those written by humans. Its capacity was ten times greater than that of the T-NLG. It was introduced in May 2020,[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-arXiv_Brown_20200722-140) and was in beta testing in June 2020. |
| 2022 | [ChatGPT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT"), an AI [chatbot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot "Chatbot") developed by [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI"), debuts in November 2022. It is initially built on top of the [GPT-3.5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3.5 "GPT-3.5")[large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model "Large language model"). While it gains considerable praise for the breadth of its knowledge base, deductive abilities, and the human-like fluidity of its natural language responses,[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-141)[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-142) it also garners criticism for, among other things, its tendency to "[hallucinate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hallucination_(artificial_intelligence) "Hallucination (artificial intelligence)")",[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-143)[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-TheVergeStackOverflow-144) a phenomenon in which an AI responds with factually incorrect answers with high confidence. The release triggers widespread public discussion on artificial intelligence and its potential impact on society.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-BloombergCowen-145)[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-146) |
| A November 2022 class action lawsuit against [Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft"), [GitHub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub "GitHub") and [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI") alleges that [GitHub Copilot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub_Copilot "GitHub Copilot"), an AI-powered code editing tool trained on public GitHub repositories, violates the copyrights of the repositories' authors, noting that the tool can generate source code which matches its training data verbatim, without providing attribution.[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-Verge_copilot-147) |
| 2023 | By January 2023, [ChatGPT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") has more than 100 million users, making it the fastest-growing consumer application to date.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-148) |
| On January 16, 2023, three artists, [Sarah Andersen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Andersen "Sarah Andersen"), Kelly McKernan, and Karla Ortiz, file a class-action [copyright infringement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement "Copyright infringement") lawsuit against [Stability AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_AI "Stability AI"), [Midjourney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midjourney "Midjourney"), and [DeviantArt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeviantArt "DeviantArt"), claiming that these companies have infringed the rights of millions of artists by training AI tools on five billion images scraped from the web without the consent of the original artists.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-149) |
| On January 17, 2023, Stability AI is sued in London by [Getty Images](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Getty_Images "Getty Images") for using its images in their training data without purchasing a license.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-cnn-getty-150)[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-GettyPress23-151) |
| Getty files another suit against Stability AI in a US district court in Delaware on February 6, 2023. In the suit, Getty again alleges copyright infringement for the use of its images in the training of [Stable Diffusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_Diffusion "Stable Diffusion"), and further argues that the model infringes Getty's [trademark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trademark "Trademark") by generating images with Getty's [watermark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watermark "Watermark").[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-ars-getty-152) |
| [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI")'s [GPT-4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-4 "GPT-4") model is released in March 2023 and is regarded as an impressive improvement over [GPT-3.5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3.5 "GPT-3.5"), with the caveat that GPT-4 retains many of the same problems of the earlier iteration.[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-153) Unlike previous iterations, GPT-4 is multimodal, allowing image input as well as text. GPT-4 is integrated into ChatGPT as a subscriber service. OpenAI claims that in their own testing the model received a score of 1410 on the [SAT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT "SAT") (94th percentile),[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-:1-154) 163 on the [LSAT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LSAT "LSAT") (88th percentile), and 298 on the [Uniform Bar Exam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Bar_Exam "Uniform Bar Exam") (90th percentile).[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-gpt4_tech_report-155) |
| On March 7, 2023, _[Nature Biomedical Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nature\_Biomedical\_Engineering "Nature Biomedical Engineering")_ writes that "it is no longer possible to accurately distinguish" human-written text from text created by large language models, and that "It is all but certain that general-purpose large language models will rapidly proliferate... It is a rather safe bet that they will change many industries over time."[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-ZDTUM-156) |
| In response to ChatGPT, [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google") releases in a limited capacity its chatbot [Google Bard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Bard "Google Bard"), based on the [LaMDA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaMDA "LaMDA") and [PaLM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PaLM "PaLM") large language models, in March 2023.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-157)[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-158) |
| On March 29, 2023, a petition of over 1,000 signatures is signed by Elon Musk, Steve Wozniak and other tech leaders, calling for a 6-month halt to what the petition refers to as "an out-of-control race" producing AI systems that its creators can not "understand, predict, or reliably control".[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-159)[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-160) |
| In May 2023, Google announces Bard's transition from LaMDA to PaLM2, a significantly more advanced language model.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-161) |
| In the last week of May 2023, a [Statement on AI Risk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statement_on_AI_risk_of_extinction "Statement on AI risk of extinction") is signed by [Geoffrey Hinton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoffrey_Hinton "Geoffrey Hinton"), [Sam Altman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Altman "Sam Altman"), [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates"), and many other prominent AI researchers and tech leaders with the following succinct message: "Mitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war."[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-162)[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-163) |
| On July 9, 2023, [Sarah Silverman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Silverman "Sarah Silverman") filed a class action lawsuit against Meta and OpenAI for copyright infringement for training their large language models on millions of authors' copyrighted works without permission.[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-164) |
| In August 2023, the New York Times, CNN, Reuters, the Chicago Tribune, Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), and other news companies blocked OpenAI's GPTBot web crawler from accessing their content, while the New York Times also updated its terms of service to disallow the use of its content in large language models.[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-165) |
| On September 13, 2023, in a serious response to growing anxiety about the dangers of AI, the US Senate holds the inaugural bipartisan "[AI Insight Forum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A.I._Insight_forums "A.I. Insight forums")", bringing together senators, CEOs, civil rights leaders and other industry reps, to further familiarize senators with the nature of AI and its risks, and to discuss needed safeguards and legislation.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-AI_Legislation_Coming-166) The event is organized by Senate Majority Leader [Chuck Schumer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Schumer "Chuck Schumer") (D-NY),[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-NYTimes_Titans-167) and is chaired by U.S. Senator [Martin Heinrich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Heinrich "Martin Heinrich") (D-N.M.), Founder and co-chair of the Senate AI Caucus.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-168) Reflecting the importance of the meeting, the forum is attended by over 60 senators,[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-CNBC_Senate_AI_Forum-169) as well as [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk") (Tesla CEO), [Mark Zuckerberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Zuckerberg "Mark Zuckerberg") (Meta CEO), [Sam Altman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Altman "Sam Altman") (OpenAI CEO), [Sundar Pichai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sundar_Pichai "Sundar Pichai") (Alphabet CEO), [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") (Microsoft co-founder), [Satya Nadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella "Satya Nadella") (Microsoft CEO), [Jensen Huang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen_Huang "Jensen Huang") (Nvidia CEO), [Arvind Krishna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arvind_Krishna "Arvind Krishna") (IBM CEO), [Alex Karp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Karp "Alex Karp") (Palantir CEO), [Charles Rivkin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Rivkin "Charles Rivkin") (chairman and CEO of the MPA), [Meredith Stiehm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meredith_Stiehm "Meredith Stiehm") (president of the Writers Guild of America West), [Liz Shuler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liz_Shuler "Liz Shuler") ([AFL-CIO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFL-CIO "AFL-CIO") President), and [Maya Wiley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_Wiley "Maya Wiley") (CEO of the [Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_Conference_on_Civil_and_Human_Rights "Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights")), among others.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-AI_Legislation_Coming-166)[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-NYTimes_Titans-167)[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-CNBC_Senate_AI_Forum-169) |
| In October 2023, AlpineGate AI Technologies Inc. CEO John Godel announced the launch of their AI Suite, AGImageAI, along with their proprietary GPT model, AlbertAGPT.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-170) |
| On October 30, 2023, US President Biden signed the _[Executive Order on the Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive\_Order\_14110 "Executive Order 14110")._[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-171)[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-172) |
| In November 2023, the first global [AI Safety Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_AI_Safety_Summit "2023 AI Safety Summit") was held in [Bletchley Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bletchley_Park "Bletchley Park") in the UK to discuss the near and far-term risks of AI and the possibility of mandatory and voluntary regulatory frameworks.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-173) 28 countries including the United States, China, and the European Union issued a declaration at the start of the summit, calling for international co-operation to manage the challenges and risks of artificial intelligence.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-2023-11-01-bletchley-declaration-full-174)[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-175) |
| On December 6, [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google") announced [Gemini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemini_(language_model) "Gemini (language model)") 1.0 Ultra, Pro, and Nano. |
| 2024 | On February 15, 2024, [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google") releases [Gemini 1.5](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gemini_1.5&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gemini 1.5 (page does not exist)") in limited beta, capable of context length up to 1 million tokens. |
| Also, on February 15, 2024, [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI") publicly announces [Sora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sora_(text-to-video_model) "Sora (text-to-video model)"), a text-to-video model for generating videos up to a minute long. |
| [Google DeepMind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind") unveils DNA prediction software AlphaFold, which helps to identify cancer and genetic diseases. |
| On February 22, [StabilityAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_AI "Stability AI") announces [Stable Diffusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_Diffusion "Stable Diffusion") 3, using a similar architecture to [Sora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sora_(text-to-video_model) "Sora (text-to-video model)"). |
| On May 14, [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google") adds an "AI overview" to Google searches. |
| On June 10, [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") announced "[Apple Intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Intelligence "Apple Intelligence")" which incorporates [ChatGPT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") into new [iPhones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPhone "IPhone") and [Siri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siri "Siri"). |
| On October 9, co-founder and CEO of [Google DeepMind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind") and [Isomorphic Labs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isomorphic_Labs "Isomorphic Labs") Sir Demis Hassabis, and Google DeepMind Director Dr. John Jumper were co-awarded the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for their work developing [AlphaFold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlphaFold "AlphaFold"), a groundbreaking AI system that predicts the 3D structure of proteins from their amino acid sequences. |
| At the Seoul Summit, leaders from the G7, the European Union, and major tech companies adopted the “Seoul Declaration for Safe, Innovative and Inclusive AI”, committing to international cooperation on AI safety, standards and innovation. |
| 2025 | On February 6, [Mistral AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mistral_AI "Mistral AI") releases Le Chat, an AI assistant able to answer up to 1,000 words per second.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-176) |
| [Stargate UAE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stargate_UAE "Stargate UAE") invests to build Europe's largest AI data center in France.[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-177) |
| Amazon is training humanoid robots to deliver packages.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-178) |
| [NLWeb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NLWeb "NLWeb"), [Project Mariner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Mariner "Project Mariner"), and [Google Flow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Flow "Google Flow") launch. |
| On February 10 and 11, [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France "France") hosts the [Artificial Intelligence Action Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_Action_Summit "Artificial Intelligence Action Summit").[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-179) 61 countries, including [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China"), [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India "India"), [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan "Japan"), France and [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada "Canada"), sign a declaration on "inclusive and sustainable" AI,[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-180) which the UK and US refused to sign.[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-181) |
| [Pope Leo XIV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pope_Leo_XIV "Pope Leo XIV") calls technologists to build AI machines that embodies love, justice, and the sacred dignity of every human life at their core.[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-182)[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence#cite_note-183) |

## Timeline of AI Major Events

**From Theory to Daily Tool: A Journey Through AI**  
 Artificial Intelligence began as a question—can machines think like humans? Over the decades, it evolved from basic rule-based systems to powerful models that generate text, art, music, and code. Today’s AI tools are part of everyday life, shaping how we search, learn, and create. As AI continues to grow, so do the questions about its ethics, limitations, and impact on society. This concise timeline highlights the key turning points in AI’s remarkable journey.

### **Early Foundations**

* **1950 – The Turing Test**  
   Alan Turing proposed a test to determine whether a machine can exhibit human-like intelligence—a foundational question that continues to shape AI ethics and design.
* **1956 – Birth of AI at Dartmouth**  
   The Dartmouth Conference, led by John McCarthy and others, officially launched the field of Artificial Intelligence and coined the term “AI.”
* **1956–1957 – Early AI Programs**  
   Programs like *Logic Theorist* and *General Problem Solver* demonstrated that computers could mimic basic reasoning and problem-solving.
* **1966 – ELIZA: The First Chatbot**  
   Joseph Weizenbaum’s ELIZA simulated a conversation with a therapist, revealing both the potential and limits of human-computer interaction.

---

### **Growth, Setbacks, and Learning**

* **1970s–1980s – Expert Systems & AI Hype**  
   Rule-based systems that mimicked decision-making were adopted in business and medicine. However, overpromises led to a loss of funding and trust—an era known as the “AI Winter.”
* **1997 – Deep Blue Beats Kasparov**  
   IBM’s Deep Blue defeated world chess champion Garry Kasparov, proving AI could master strategic games once thought too complex for machines.

---

### **Modern Machine Learning Era**

* **2006 – Deep Learning Resurgence**  
   Advances in computing power and big data revived neural networks. The term "deep learning" gained popularity and kickstarted modern AI research.
* **2011 – IBM Watson Wins *Jeopardy!***  
   Watson triumphed over human champions, showcasing AI’s ability to understand language, facts, and wordplay—though real-world applications proved more challenging.
* **2012 – Image Recognition Breakthrough (AlexNet)**  
   A deep learning model dramatically improved performance in image classification, paving the way for AI in facial recognition, medical imaging, and more.
* **2014 – Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)**  
   GANs enabled the creation of synthetic but realistic images, forming the foundation for modern image-generating AI tools like DALL·E and Midjourney.

---

### **AI Becomes Everyday**

* **2016 – AlphaGo Defeats Go Champion**  
   DeepMind’s AlphaGo beat Lee Sedol in the ancient game of Go, surprising experts and demonstrating AI’s growing ability to handle intuition-based tasks.
* **2018 – Google’s BERT Transforms Language Understanding**  
   BERT improved search engines and translation tools by better understanding context, marking a leap in natural language processing.

---

### **The Generative AI Boom**

* **2022 – ChatGPT Release**  
   OpenAI launched ChatGPT to the public, making conversational AI accessible to everyday users. It quickly became a widely adopted productivity and creativity tool.
* **2023 – Multimodal AI & GPT-4**  
   Models like GPT-4, Gemini, and Claude 2 introduced multimodal capabilities—understanding not just text but images, charts, and more.
* **2024 – Open Source AI Surge**  
   Community-driven models like LLaMA, Mistral, and Mixtral offered free, customizable alternatives to commercial tools, pushing AI accessibility even further.
